title: The brooch is back: update your entire wardrobe with one simple styling twist
text:
Brooches are newsworthy again. Lady Hale, the president of the Supreme Court, wore a big silvery spider pinned to her lapel last month as she determined that Boris Johnson’s prorogation of Parliament was unlawful. Her sartorial subliminal messaging went viral on the web (was she saying he’s stuck in a web of lies?) offering a fresh reminder of the almighty power jewellery can have when utilised in one’s wardrobe.

Brooches have often served a purpose beyond decoration; a Victorian cameo might hold a portrait of someone important to the wearer, a medieval amulet could apparently protect its owner from harm. They are truly ancient ornaments, dating back to the Bronze Age, but brooches lost their...
